Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Maintaining Social Relationships through Periods of Protracted Insecurity in Refugee Communities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Global displacement due to forced migration is currently at historically high levels. Many of those refugees have experienced decades of violence and insecurity, making it difficult to maintain relationships. Researchers have established that strong community, kin, and network relations are essential to social and political stability. This project, which trains a graduate student in methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, explores how these relationships are maintained during extended periods of precarity. Findings will be disseminated to organizations that manage and develop policy related to refugee resettlement. The research also fosters international scientific cooperation, and broadens the participation of an underrepresented group in the sciences.

Mariam Banahi, under the supervision of Dr. Veena Das of The Johns Hopkins University, will explore how kinship is conceived and affective relationships are maintained in the face of both protracted insecurity and periods of crisis. The research will be conducted in Hamburg, Germany, home to the largest Afghan community in Europe, and will employ anthropological tools of data collection, such as participant-observation, structured and semi-structured interviews, informal, open-ended conversations, budget surveys, genealogical charts, and household budgets. Though comprising one of the largest refugee groups worldwide, migration and refugee studies have largely ignored Afghans and Afghanistan. Also, Afghan conceptions of kin networks conceive of relatedness as both inclusive and beyond immediate blood relationships to larger ethno-linguistic, tribal, religious, and national communities. By investigating the practices and labors through which Afghans forge relations in spite of conflict, loss, and death, this research will contribute to theories on violence and chronic insecurity as they affect the families. Moreover, by attending to the Afghan family, this research will explore the often elided consequences of conflict to investigate refugee kinship and Muslim communities in Germany. Lastly, this research will foster greater interest in the academic study of Afghanistan through teaching and publications, as well as encourage collaborative partnerships between diverse actors engaged with emigrant communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Science Foundation Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement grant supported the research project, “Maintaining Social Relationships through Periods of Protracted Insecurity in Refugee Communities” (Award #1658464). This research investigated how recently arrived Afghan emigrants in Hamburg negotiated the apparent discordance between Germany’s “Welcome Culture” and governmental policies that define Afghanistan as a “safe” country. In the case of recently arrived Afghan emigrants in Germany, the temporality of protracted warfare and insecurity was often elided in favor of focusing on definite moments of crisis, in particular, the “Refugee/Migrant Crisis” facing Europe. German governmental policies (including local funding of integration initiatives), as well as media discourse, often sought to reduce funding directed at serving Afghan asylum-seekers and hinder their efforts to remain in Germany—posing fresh, often insurmountable risks. The research considers how recent political events have shaped Germany and Germans’ reactions to it by considering Islamophobia and other forms of inclusion and exclusion. For Afghans, the process of making a new life, including securing legal status and accessing/distributing resources, is deeply embedded in the shifting intensities of familial relations that have been threatened by war and material precarity. 

The research consisted of ethnographic fieldwork among Afghan emigrants in Hamburg, Germany. The Co-PI compiled data using qualitative methods based on the research design, including semi-structured, informal interviews, media analysis, and participant observation throughout the research period. Participant observation was conducted with non-profit organizations and initiatives targeting emigrant communities in Hamburg, accompanying Afghan emigrants to appointments at respective Foreigner Registration Offices [Ausländerbehörde], unemployment offices [Jobcenter], asylum interview preparation sessions, with advocacy groups to access assistance, and participating in the intimate spaces of the family.

This project contributes to debates within anthropology on kinship by studying communities disrupted by violence, displacement, and forms of protracted insecurity. This research focuses on the specificity of the Afghan community, which has largely been ignored and subsumed under discussions of larger Muslim communities in Germany. The Co-PI’s work will contribute to efforts by anthropologists and other social scientists to rejuvenate the study of Afghans and Afghanistan in the post-2001 period, raising questions on the temporalities and boundedness of war, its aftermath, and inheritances. This research will also offer a more nuanced understanding of the ongoing "European refugee/migrant crisis" and the resurgence of the xenophobia and Islamophobia in Germany (and Europe).

Over the course of the research period and since its closure, the Co-PI has presented preliminary findings at academic conferences and workshops in the United States, Germany, Portugal, and Norway. In the coming year, the Co-PI will disseminate findings to communities of interest in Germany and the United States at additional academic conferences and through publications to reach broader publics. The Co-PI is scheduled to share her results with a diverse group of academics and practitioners at the 2018 Annual Meeting of the American Anthropological Association. In her teaching, the Co-PI has drawn from this research in her most recent course at Johns Hopkins University’s Department of Anthropology. The course, “The Family at War” aimed to educate students on major debates in kinship studies to then show how anthropologists study kinship in under conditions of conflict, war, “post”-conflict, as well as in marginalized communities. The Co-PI is working on her doctoral dissertation and is currently preparing two articles for submission to peer-reviewed academic journals. In the next year, the Co-PI hopes to formally share findings with policymakers, social workers, translators, and activists in the United States and Germany to help better address the challenges of immigration and the needs of emigrant communities.
